abstract.p: With the aid of an online survey, the purpose of this study is to examine financial preferences; social, environmental and ethical concerns; and socio-demographic characteristics of Australian socially responsible (SR) investors. The study advances knowledge of SR investors’ profiles and their motivations when making investment decisions. Based on a sample of 145 investors, our findings suggest that SR investors seek financial return as well as non-financial benefits. Social conscience and social health issues, as opposed to environmental issues, are relevant to investors. Interestingly, investor risk tolerance is a relatively unimportant factor in the choice of SR investments. Finally, in terms of socio-demographics, SR investors tend to be middle-aged, be middle-income professionals and have tertiary qualifications.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: Socially responsible investment (SRI) is an investment process that considers the social and environmental consequences of investments, both positive and negative, within the context of rigorous financial analysis. It is a process of identifying and investing in companies that meet certain standards of corporate social responsibility (SIF, 2003). The SRI industry has experienced rapid growth in recent times. According to the Social Investment Forum Trends Report from 2010 (SIF, 2010), professionally managed assets with SRI strategies amounted to US$3.07 trillion. This level of investment represents an increase of more than 380% from US$639 billion in 1995. However, general assets under professional management increased only 260% from US$7 trillion to US$25.2 trillion over the same period. From 2007–2010 the universe of managed assets has remained relatively stable while SRI assets have grown. These figures indicate that the importance of the SRI industry is growing fast and is becoming a phenomenon that has to be taken seriously by both researchers and business experts (Nilsson, 2008). However, the factors that lead investors to choose SRI products are still not well understood.

In Australia, as stated by Cummings (2000), the mainstream SRI movement began in 1981 with the establishment of August Investment Proprietary Limited (in 1989, it became the Australian Ethical Investment Trust). In 1999, the Ethical Investment Association (EIA) was formed. Among other things, the EIA instigated a series of SRI benchmarking reports in Australia, supported by private stakeholders and the Australian Government Department of Environment and Heritage. The EIA changed its name in 2007, becoming the Responsible Investment Association Australasia (RIAA). The 2010 RIAA annual report on SRI (RIAA, 2010) shows how the average return of responsible investment (Australian Shares, Overseas Shares and Balanced Growth managed funds) outperformed the average mainstream fund over a period of 7 years. With regard to total funds under management, managed responsible investment portfolios rose 10% during the 2010 financial year from AU$14.02 billion to AU$15.41 billion. The broader market of managed portfolios rose 7% (RIAA, 2010). The market for SRI, and more precisely, for SRI mutual funds, is growing fast globally and, in particular, in Australia. However, there are few studies exploring the determinants of SRI, especially for the individual private investor.

Accordingly, this paper aims to expand our understanding of socially responsible (SR) investor profiles. To do so, an exploratory study is designed to address the following questions: who are SR investors? And, what are their motivations when investing in socially responsible products? When SR investors face investment decisions they take into account not only the classic financial criteria but also socially responsible criteria. Anand and Cowton (1993) and Hallerbach et al. (2004) suggest that a generalization of utility theory might be appropriate via multi-criteria decision-making models. To do this, it is essential to know the financial and non-financial criteria affecting SRI decisions and, thus, informing this question is another objective that we seek to address in the current paper.

We report the characteristics and motivations of SR investors. More specifically, with the aid of an online survey we examine financial preferences, social, environmental and ethical concerns, and socio-demographic characteristics of Australian investors to advance our understanding of SR investors’ profiles and their motivations when making investment decisions. Based on a sample of 145 investors, our findings suggest that SR investors tend to be middle-aged, be middle-income professionals, and have tertiary qualifications. SR investors seem to seek financial return as well as non-financial benefits. Interestingly, investor risk tolerance is a relatively unimportant factor in the choice of SRIs. We assess the relevance of various social, environment and ethical concerns (SEE) to investors. A principal components analysis (PCA) shows, the relevant issues can be categorized as social conscience, environmental, social/health, and social/environmental. However, the most relevant factors in determining investment are social conscience and social health. For both academia and the SRI industry this study provides useful knowledge on the profile of SR investors, given the growing proportion of investments subject to SEE criteria.

The remainder of the paper is organized as follows. The next section presents a literature review on the three dimensions of SR investor profiling. In Section 3 the research design is presented, while Section 4 presents our results. Finally, discussion and conclusions are presented.

sec.title: 2. Literature review
sec.p: There is a range of literature, with mixed results, on the relation between corporate social responsibility and financial performance (see for example Choi et al., 2010; Lee et al., 2009).1 Artiach et al. (2010) investigate factors that determine corporate SR performance. At the mutual fund level Lee et al. (2010) assess the impact of imposing SR screens, when selecting the portfolio, on the performance of the managed fund. However, at the individual investor level the formulation of a comprehensive profile of SR investors has not yet been well developed in the literature, although several attempts have been made. Previous research with regard to this profiling effort is presented in the following sections, focusing on three different groups of variables: financial; SEE; and socio-demographic.

From this literature review we formulate predictions as to the relations between the SR investor and the financial, SEE or socio-demographic variables. We note each of these predictions in the literature review and summarize them in Table 1.

sec.title: 2.1. Financial profile: risk and performance
sec.p: In a survey of 388 actual SR investors and 650 potential SR investors, Woodward (2000) finds that while just over 7% of respondents list their main concern is to improve society, more than 29% wish to avoid harming it and the overall majority, over 62%, wish to combine these objectives. She finds financial objectives are not the same among all the SR investors. Some 78% of respondents are interested in achieving capital growth suggesting, in the author’s opinion, that this could form part of a long-term strategy. Only 12.9% of investors are focused on obtaining a regular income. Over 81% of the investors identify long-term needs as their main savings objective. Respondents are also asked to indicate the proportion of their portfolio invested using ethical criteria. Over 50% have more than half of their funds invested in SR products.

Lewis and Mackenzie (2000) find that around 42% (41%) of SR investors believe that SRI gives lower (similar) return than conventional investment and around 19% (58%) consider them riskier (no less risky). The authors also find an average of 31% of the portfolio invested in SR products, but 80% of investors have ‘mixed’ portfolios (socially and non-socially responsible products combined) and just 20% said to have their entire portfolio invested in SR products.

Nilsson (2008) finds that when asked their ‘perceptions’ of risk and return, approximately one-quarter of the respondents perceive that SR products (mutual funds) perform worse than conventional investment products; 20% believe that SR products (mutual funds) will outperform conventional mutual funds in the long run, while 52% of investors think that financial return will not be different than that achieved by conventional mutual funds. Similarly, 63% of respondents perceive investment risk to be the same in regular and SRI funds. These results, as pointed out by Nilsson (2008), differ from those of Lewis and Mackenzie (2000), where a higher percentage of investors think that SR products perform worse than conventional investments.

McLachlan and Gardner (2004) find no significant difference between the importance given to financial return by SR investors and conventional investors. However, further examination of their data shows that compared with SR investors, conventional investors rate financial return as slightly more important. Williams (2007) also finds financial returns to have very little power in explaining the SRI choice. Similarly, Haigh (2008), finds that financial performance is not significantly correlated with investment intention.2

This group of studies leads to predictions on financial and decision-making characteristics relevant to SR investors. Specifically, we expect SR investors to be concerned about financial and non-financial characteristics and conscious of capital growth vs. income yielding investments. With respect to risk we predict investors will be more risk tolerant. It is noted that Nilsson and Lewis and Mackenzie find investors do not perceive SRI funds to be more risky. However, portfolio theory would imply an increased risk due to reduced diversification in SR portfolios.

sec.title: 2.2. Social, environmental and ethical (SEE) profile
sec.p: Investors may adopt a positive (inclusionary) or negative (exclusionary) approach when selecting SRI opportunities. Lee et al. noted that SIF (2005) stated that more than 80% of relevant funds adopt an exclusionary approach. However, more recently SRI screens are being applied in an inclusionary context, with investors seeking leaders in social practices (SIF website). While we recognize that observed approaches may blend elements of both polar extremes, we predict that the more socially responsible an investor, the more likely they will follow an inclusionary approach. However, we also follow a series of studies that identify factors investors tend to avoid.

Haigh (2008), using a survey approach, examines why investors may be attracted to social funds and the information the investor uses to evaluate funds. His results indicate that the most important information are the details on the social aspects of the fund, the screening method used, the managerial experience and the listing of stocks.

Rosen et al. (1991) asks respondents to list factors considered more important in determining whether a company’s behavior can be considered socially responsible. From the responses, the authors consider six groups of SEE criteria: environment, labor relations, military, marketing and finance, politics and individual rights. Each of the six categories presents examples of negative and positive investment behaviors. The two categories most frequently mentioned are environment and labor relations (28% each), whereas the least popular area is individual rights. Some 83% of responses relate to a negative investment strategy. This trend holds across all categories except for marketing and financial issues. In this area, the investors frequently mention the types of products the firm should produce.

Nilsson (2008) considers five major categories of issues with regard to SEE: human rights, corruption, workplace rights, environmental care, and production of harmful goods. The results show that investors holding a higher proportion of their portfolio in SR products generally show stronger ‘pro-social’ attitudes than those investing less. From Rosen et al. (1991) and Nilsson (2008) we specify our first general prediction on SEE concerns, presented in Table 1. Specifically, the more socially responsible the investor is, the more SEE issues concern them.

Anand and Cowton (1993) analyze the responses of 125 clients of EIRIS Services Limited, an ethical investment information service based in London. The clients are asked to specify the grounds on which they wished to avoid investing in companies. The questionnaire contains questions of the type: ‘Do you want to exclude…?’ under 14 criteria: advertising, alcohol, animals, sales to military purchasers, gambling, newspaper production & television, nuclear power, spread of overseas interests, proportion of business overseas, political contributions, size of company, South Africa, tobacco and financial institutions. South Africa is the first ranked, followed by sales to military purchasers and tobacco. The fourth position is nuclear power followed by financial institutions, gambling, animals, political contributions. The last positions are for advertising, alcohol, spread of overseas interests, proportion of business overseas, size of company and in the last place, newspaper production and television.

A PCA is applied to capture the more general attributes underlying the criteria. Five components are extracted which together explain more than 60% of the variation in the data, with the first component alone explaining almost one quarter. For example, Component 1 depends heavily on nuclear power, animals, sales to military purchasers, political contributions and financial institutions. The authors refer to it as the ‘Post-Industrial’ factor, reflecting the preferences of ‘middle-aged investors’ whose values were formed during 1960s. Component 2 combines exclusions based on alcohol, gambling and tobacco, and is thus labeled the ‘Sin Stock’ factor. Component 3 (spread of overseas interests, proportion of business overseas and advertising) is labeled as a ‘mistrust’ factor. The fourth component (size of company and newspaper production and television) they call ‘undue influence’, while the fifth component (sales to military purchasers and South Africa), is labeled a ‘human rights/pacifist’ factor.

Woodward (2000) also analyzes the importance given to different SR criteria by UK investors. She distinguishes between product/service-based criteria and process/philosophy criteria. The first category includes criteria related to the provision of health care, tobacco production, armaments, and nuclear power. The product/service-based criterion considered to be most important is the nuclear power criterion, with 62% of the respondents extremely concerned. The next most important are biodiversity, manufacture of chemicals of concern and sustainable timber. The second category concerns either the process employed in producing or the philosophical approach adopted by organizations. The most highly ranked process/philosophy-based criterion concerns water pollution, followed by climate change, air pollution and environmental management – all of them with more than 50% of respondents extremely concerned with the issue.3

McLachlan and Gardner (2004) compare SR investors and conventional investors with respect to the importance given to SR criteria when making investment decisions, using a four-point scale. Nuclear weapons is the issue which concerns more SR investors in Australia, followed by racism/sexism, trade with oppressive regimes, pornography and tobacco. Issues ranked lowest are pesticide use, alcohol and gambling.

In Table 1 we begin the Investment Style section with a general prediction from Haigh (2008) that SR fund investors are more likely to have a positive or inclusionary strategy. However, we also recognize that, as shown in Woodward (2000) and Nilsson (2008), a variety of issues concern SR investors. Hence, they may also seek to avoid particular industries, companies or countries. We follow with more specific issues, following Anand and Cowton (1993).

Haigh (2008) examines different levels of information asymmetry experienced by investors and the impact the asymmetry has on investor choices. Where an investor engages an advisor, weaker information asymmetry is expected. We use this discussion to formulate our prediction on the decision-making style, and suggest investors visiting a financial advisor will invest a greater proportion of the portfolio in SRI-profiled funds.

sec.title: 2.3. Socio-demographic profile
sec.p: The socio-demographic variables used to profile SR investors include gender, age, education, place of residence, living alone and income. In general, SR investors tend to be middle-aged, mainly female and with tertiary qualifications. SR investors are not in the higher income bracket, as measured relative to average income (Rosen et al., 1991). There are some variations to this general conclusion. Woodward’s (2000) results are consistent with the exception of gender. Lewis and Mackenzie (2000) show that SR investors are frequently middle-aged and middle-income professionals. Nilsson’s (2008) results are consistent with regard to age and education; however, the other three socio-demographic variables (income, place of residence, and age) do not significantly impact SR investors’ behavior.

Several authors study the socio-demographic characteristics of SR investors in an Australian setting, including Beal and Goyen (1998), Tippet and Leung (2001), McLachlan and Gardner (2004), Williams (2007) and Haigh (2008). Beal and Goyen (1998) survey 825 investors in ‘Earth Sanctuaries Ltd’ (ESL). Their results show how ESL shareholders are generally older and more likely to be female than the total shareholder population. They are more likely to be metropolitan residents than regional, with significantly higher levels of education, socio-economic status and household assets.

In contrast, McLachlan and Gardner (2004) find no evidence of differences in age, educational level, or income for Australian SR investors (based on a comparative examination of 55 conventional and 54 SR investors). However, conventional investors dominate SR investors in the two age categories at the extreme ends of range (16–25 and >65), while SR investors dominate conventional investors in the mid-range categories. Also counter to previous research, SR investors are not found to have higher education levels than conventional investors. However, the modal pattern suggests that SR investors might have somewhat higher education levels.

Williams (2007) presents a cross-country study of five countries: Australia, Canada, Germany, the UK and the US, and the results vary across jurisdictions. Income appears to have some influence in Australia and Canada, but not elsewhere. Community size is important in Australia. Age appears to be important in Germany, although the importance of social performance appears to increase with age, contrary to the author’s hypothesis. Income appears to be significant across all countries, with SR investors having higher income levels than conventional investors. Overall, contrary to the findings of several studies (Rosen et al., 1991; Tippet and Leung, 2001), Williams’ (2007) demographics appear to explain very little and, in general, the results are not statistically significant as in McLachlan and Gardner (2004).

Haigh (2008) uses an internet questionnaire survey completed by 382 respondents, current and former social investors from Australasia, North America and Europe. His results are in line with previous findings. A slight majority of the respondents are male, most are living alone and the majority have completed a form of postgraduate education. Junkus and Berry (2010) find that the typical US SR investor is female and more likely to be single, younger, less wealthy, and better educated than their non-SR counterparts.

In summary, while there is some variation in the role of demographics, there is also variation in sample and instruments. Conclusions with respect to age, education, gender and income are relatively consistent.

sec.title: 3. Research design
sec.p: The core aim of the current study is to profile SR investors in Australian investment funds. To this end, our research design has two main elements. We begin by implementing a broad-based survey aimed at collecting a representative sample across a wide variety of characteristics of SR investors. We then use these data in ordered probit regression analyses, seeking to uncover the important dimensions of the SRI profile in a multivariate setting.

sec.title: 3.1. Sample and data collection
sec.p: SR investors are a small but established and unique subset of the total investor universe. We do not seek to compare the SR group with other groups, but aim to identify the characteristics and preferences of SR investors. Thus, the population of interest in our study is investors that already invest in SRI-profiled funds or are willing to invest in them. SRI mutual funds represent a small proportion of the total number of mutual funds, and some mutual fund providers do not offer their customers any SRI funds (Nilsson, 2008). Hence, we could not randomly sample the general population since the number of SR investors is likely to be few compared with the general population of conventional investors. To avoid this problem, we obtained our sample of investors via an online survey available for Australian investors from the RIAA.4

Based on a literature review and discussions with experts in the field of SRI, a preliminary questionnaire was prepared. It was tested on market researchers and academic experts, incorporating comments/suggestions into the final questionnaire which consists of 37 questions, a mixture of open-ended and Likert-scaled questions.5 The link for the online survey was displayed on the RIAA website and also published in their newsletter. There are 145 usable questionnaire responses from current SR investors.6

sec.title: 3.2. Questionnaire development
sec.p: The questionnaire is designed to capture, for each respondent, their SEE concerns, their financial preferences including investment style, preferred investment characteristic and risk tolerance, and their demographic details. There are 37 questions in the questionnaire, grouped into three parts: (1) Socially Responsible Concerns; (2) Financial Issues, including investment style, decision-making style and risk tolerance; and (3) Socio-demographic Information.

The questionnaire was self-designed by the authors with exception of questions relating to risk tolerance and the use of a financial advisor, for which we use Ethical Investment Services Risk Profile questionnaire, kindly provided by Janice Carpenter, senior adviser.7 The issues covered in the questionnaire are based on our review of the literature and discussion with industry representatives. Similarly, based on our literature review, we make predictions as to the relation between a measure of the ‘intensity’ of being an SR investor and their SEE concerns, investment styles, decision-making styles, risk tolerance levels and the demographics. These predictions are summarized in Table 1.

Many of these issues are empirical questions; hence, our aim to profile SR investors. However, the growing literature does provide some direction. In summary, we expect SR investors to be ‘pro-social’ (Nilsson, 2008), adopt inclusionary strategies yet possibly avoid particular areas of investment. Goldreyer and Diltz (1999) find some evidence to show that funds which employ inclusionary screens outperform those that do not. Given that SR investors do not focus purely on financial characteristics, it is reasonable to expect they are less concerned with the risk–return relation and, hence, less risk averse (i.e. more risk tolerant). Modern portfolio theory would imply that the investor focuses on maximum return for minimum risk. Our demographic predictions are based on past studies identified in Section 2.3. In Table 1 we also cross-reference the predictions to the subsequent probit regression analysis, defining the empirical proxies and associated notation that we employ.

sec.title: 3.3. Descriptive data analysis
sec.p: About one-third of our sample adopt an exclusionary approach (negative criteria) to their investment strategy, 6% are inclusionary (positive criteria) and 45% use a combination of strategies. The majority of our sample are in the two extremes; 35% invest between 0–25%, and 35% invest between 75–100% of their budget. The majority of investors (61%) indicate that they would like to exclude some specific companies from their portfolio. Only about a quarter of the sample would exclude regions (mostly communist or dictatorship regimes). Many noted a preference to support Australian companies. Some 53% of respondents would exclude specific sectors, with mining being the most noted industry for exclusion. When looking for a fund, the most important criteria nominated is management reputation, closely followed by current performance, exit fees and past performance. Annual fees and initial fees also rank, on average, as quite important. About half of the respondents look for capital growth, whereas 39% seek a combination of growth and regular income. A slight majority seek support of a financial advisor, even though two-thirds believe that they have at least a reasonable understanding of investment markets. Safety is a concern, with 37% indicating that safety is more important than higher returns. However, 35% seek higher returns, with 26% being neutral to the trade-off between safety and returns.

The majority of participants, 66% (81%) have an investment horizon less than 7 (5) years. This long-term perspective is supported in answering other related questions, where 85% indicate that they will accept a fall in their investment if long-term return is good. The majority of respondents can be classified as prudent (73%), that is, they seek a balanced portfolio to achieve their medium to long-term financial goals, while just 16% are classified as ‘aggressive’.

The participants also identified their level of social, ethical and/or environmental concerns, and responses are presented in Table 2. On the basis of the mean score from a rating scale of 0–4, the top 10 issues of concern are: Water pollution (3.59), Climate change and greenhouse gases (3.57), Pollution (3.51), Nuclear power (3.37), Human rights (3.33), Biodiversity (3.26), Environmental management policy reporting and performance (3.25), Chemicals (3.21), Sustainable timber (3.19) and finally, Military issues (3.14). The least important issues are abortion and trade unions.

sec.p: The majority of our sample of SR investors are young–middle-aged. There are more female (74%) than male (26%) SR investor respondents. Of our sample, 72% have no dependents, although 68% are married/defacto. The participants are well educated, with 84% having a Bachelors degree or higher. Some 42% of the respondents are on a higher than average income.8 The majority of our sample (67%) are not religious, and a slight majority (56%) live in a big city (defined as more than 2.5 million habitants). Investors prefer visits to an investment advisor for initial contact when deciding to invest (41%), but they prefer the internet (37%) in order to follow transactions once the initial contact has been established.

sec.title: 3.4. Dependent variable
sec.p: To test the predictions outlined in Table 1 we begin by following several authors from the economic psychology literature, and use the proportion invested in a socially responsible way as a proxy for ‘moral commitment’ (Lewis and Mackenzie, 2000). Nilsson (2008) defines socially responsible investment behavior as ‘how much the consumer invests in SRI’ and presents a model of expected influential variables on SRI behavior.

The dependent variable is then defined in terms of categories for the percentage of the budget used to invest in SR mutual funds representing “Socially Responsible Investment Behavior”. Specifically, an ordered categorical variable (0, 1, 2) is created to represent three groups:

SRI is the dependent variable in ordered probit models designed to test the predictions outlined in Table 1. We consider three key groups of factors influencing SRI behavior: (1) a group of SEE variables; (2) a group of financial variables incorporating investor preferences for return, risk and types of investment; and (3) a number of socio-demographic variables.

sec.title: 3.5. Independent variables: SEE considerations
sec.p: SEE concerns are captured using 37 items on the questionnaire. To reduce the dimensionality of these potential proxies, a PCA is conducted on the responses to these items. Table 3 lists these 37 items and shows the first four components. Eigenvalues for components 1, 2, 3, 4 and 5 were 11.03, 3.55, 2.35, 1.98 and 1.73, respectively, while the first nine components have eigenvalues > 1. For reasons of parsimony we adopt a higher cut-off – selecting four components allows 50% of the variance to be explained. We denote these as: SEEPC1; SEEPC2; SEEPC3; SEEPC4

sec.p: The majority of the SEE concerns load positively (and reasonably uniformly) on to the first component, explaining 29% of the variance. Reference to the various loadings suggests that this variable can be interpreted as a social conscience factor, with the highest loading on community, equal opportunity, human rights, breast milk substitutes and bribery. We label the second component as an environmental variable, with higher loadings on issues including mining, nuclear power, pollution, sustainable timber, water pollution and intensive farming. Fur and animal testing also load onto this component. The third component covers social/health issues, reflected by the fact that the most relevant SEE concerns for this component are abortion, alcohol, breast milk substitutes, intensive farming and meat sale, fur and tobacco marketing. The fourth component is deemed to reflect a social/environmental component, with highest loadings from gambling, greenhouse gases, nuclear power and tobacco. These results are somewhat similar to those obtained by Rosen et al. (1991) – they identify the two categories most frequently mentioned by investors as issues of concern are environment and labor relations.

sec.title: 3.6.1. Investment strategy/screening process
sec.p: A specific survey question asked whether respondents adopted an inclusionary (positive) or exclusionary (negative) investment style. Accordingly, two dummy variables are created: DInc (DExc) = 1 if inclusionary (exclusionary), 0 otherwise. An alternative way to consider an exclusionary/inclusionary style is to capture the extent to which the investor would screen in terms of company, region or sector. Specifically, three dummy variables are created: DSCom; DSReg and DSSec. Respondents were also asked to specify which industries, from a list of 13, that they would screen. Some 45% indicate that they would screen mining, while the remainder of responses were thinly spread across the other categories. Hence, just one further dummy variable is created: DSMin = 1 excluding mining, 0 otherwise.

sec.title: 3.6.2. Decision-making style
sec.p: To capture the respondents’ decision-making style, a dummy variable is created to reflect if the investor has difficulties when making choices and seeks help or not: DHelp = 1 if investor seeks help, 0 otherwise.

A PCA is performed on the nine items. The first component has an eigenvalue of 4.4 and explains about half of the variance. The second and third components have eigenvalues of 1.4 and 1.3, respectively, and all three together explain 78% of the variance. Accordingly, three variables are created:

The first component is essentially a general fund variable with a focus on fees. The second component represents age and size of the fund, while the third is a performance variable.

Two dummy variables are created to reflect desired growth/income characteristics of the investment, where: DLTG: = 1 if the investor wants their investments to provide long-term capital growth, 0 otherwise; DGI: = 1 if the investor wants their investments to provide both growth/ income, 0 otherwise.9

sec.title: 3.6.4. Risk profile
sec.p: A risk tolerance variable (RTol) is created using PCA on the three survey questions that address the investor preferences to invest in cash, risk versus higher returns and views on the riskiness of share investments. The responses to the three questions are reduced to one variable, given by the first principal component (the eigenvalue on the first component was 1.8 and explains 60% of the variance).

Respondents were asked to self-assess their understanding of investment markets. Based on the responses, an ordered categorical variable (UNDIM) is created (0, 1, 2, 3, 4), increasing in their level of understanding (where 0 = no understanding through to 4 = excellent understanding). This variable is used as a control in assessing the relevance of risk tolerance levels to investment decisions.

sec.title: 3.6.5. Investment horizon
sec.p: An ordered categorical variable (HOR) taking values from 0–4, representing the investment horizon, where 0 = less than 2 years; 1 = 2–3 years; 2 = 3–5 years; 3 = 5–7 years and 4 = >7 years. The investor’s long-term investment focus (LTERM1) is captured using an ordered categorical variable (0–4) where 0 (4) represents those investors strongly agreeing (strongly disagreeing) that they would not mind a short-term loss providing the long-term return is good. Similarly, those willing to keep an investment as part of a long-term strategy, even if there was a short-term loss (15% or more in a year) allows the creation of an additional ordered categorical variable (0–4) (LTERM2).

sec.title: 4. Ordered probit regression results
sec.p: A series of ordered probit models are estimated to assess if the level of investment in SR funds can be explained by different SEE concerns, investment strategies, decision-making style, risk tolerance and demographics. Demographic variables are included in all models as a set of controls. The results are presented in Table 4. The quadratic hill-climbing approach is adopted and Huber/White robust covariances used.10 The dependent variable is SRI, an ordered categorical variable defined earlier. As a concession to degrees of freedom concerns, we adopt a ‘grouping’ strategy in our estimations – that is, we consider in discrete groups, independent variables around the themes discussed earlier. The independent variables are specified in the first column of each pair of columns. The coefficients are reported with the p-value in parentheses.

The dependent variable is SRI, an ordered categorical variable where SRIi = 0 for those that invest 0–25% of their budget in SR funds; SRIi = 1 for those that invest 25–75% of their budget in SR funds; and SRIi = 2 for those that invest 75–100% of their budget in SR funds. The independent variables are specified in the first column of each pair of columns definitions are provided in Table 1. The coefficients are reported with the p-value in parentheses.

sec.title: 4.1. Baseline results
sec.p: Regression 1 provides the baseline results in which just the demographic variables are included. In this first case, only two variables produce significant coefficient estimates: the university (10% level) and female (1% level) dummy variables. In both instances the predicted positive relation is observed – both women and university-educated respondents tend to have a higher portion of their investment budget devoted to SR funds. In contrast, our sample does not support any relation between income, age, urban domicile, having dependants, religious beliefs or being married and the level of SR fund investment. These results are consistent with the literature summary presented in Section 2.3 with the exception that we do not find a significant age relation. The full set of demographic variables is retained as a set of controls in all remaining regressions.

sec.title: 4.2. The role of SEE
sec.p: The variables constructed from the PCA of the SEE concerns are combined with the demographic variables in regression model 2. These results show that the first and third components are both significant (at the 5% level). As discussed above, these components reflect the social conscience and social health issues of investors. Interestingly, components 2 and 4 tend to reflect environmental issues and are not significant. It seems that investors with an environmental focus are not seeking to invest a higher proportion in SR funds. The social concerns and health issues focus on community, equal opportunity, human rights, breast milk substitutes, bribery, abortion, alcohol, intensive farming and meat sale and fur/tobacco marketing. Australian SR investors are less focused on environmental issues. Prior studies that focus on investor preferences show environmental issues are more relevant (see, for example, Nilsson, 2008).

It is noted in Regression 2 that religion has a negative and significant estimated coefficient, suggesting that investors who are religious are less likely to invest in SR funds. This finding is counterintuitive. One explanation may be the heterogeneity in the religious group. Brammer et al. (2007) explore the relationship between religious denomination and individual attitudes to corporate social responsibility (CSR) within the context of a large sample of respondents drawn from 20 countries. Evidence found by the authors suggests that, broadly, religious individuals do not prioritize the responsibilities of the firm differently, but do tend to hold broader perceptions of the social responsibilities of business than non-religious individuals. However, they find that this is neither true for all religious groups, nor for all areas of CSR. Instead of observing a clear difference between religious and non-religious individuals, the authors find a notable degree of heterogeneity within the group of religious individuals.

sec.title: 4.3. The role of investment style
sec.p: Regression 3 augments the demographic considerations with the broad investment style considerations – namely, whether the investor takes on an inclusionary or exclusionary strategy to their investment. First, we see that the same two demographics (university education and being female) retain their significance. However, we see that having either an inclusionary or an exclusionary style is not related to the level of SR investment. This finding does not support our prediction. It is perhaps indicative of an evolving environment for the SR investors.

Traditionally, an exclusionary approach has been adopted in the formation of SR portfolios (Knoll, 2002). Yet our raw questionnaire results, as discussed in Section 3.3 show that while investors are keen to exclude particular industries or countries, they are also conscious of adopting an inclusionary strategy focusing on domestic investment – akin to the well-documented ‘home bias’ phenomenon. Furthermore, 45% of our sample investors adopted a combination of strategies. These results are further explored in Regression model 4. This specification incorporates more specific investment style considerations: namely, screening on country; screening on region; screening on sector; screening on mining; and the level of investment devoted to domestic companies. The results show that respondents who screen on the basis of region are more likely to invest a higher proportion in SR funds (10% level). The other possible forms of screening seem unimportant. The SR investors in this sample do not adopt general inclusionary/exclusionary processes. However, they are conscious of regional screens.

sec.title: 4.4. Other considerations
sec.p: Regression model 5 augments the demographic variable set with: the ‘help’ dummy; growth and growth/ income dummies; and the three principal components extracted from the investment characteristics variables (InvCPC1; InvCPC2; InvCPC3). Of these variables, the first and third investment characteristics components are statistically significant. Specifically, the first component represents ‘fund fees’ and has a negative impact on the level of investment in SR funds, and fund financial performance a positive impact. These findings are consistent with the broader literature (Lewis and Mackenzie, 2000; Nilsson, 2009; Rosen et al., 1991; Woodward, 2000) and indicates that SR investors are seeking financial return as well as the non-financial benefit.

Finally, we have Regression model 6 which augments the demographic variables with risk tolerance (RTol), while additionally controlling for understanding of markets (UNDIM) and whether the investor has a long-term investment focus (LTERM1 and LTERM2). Our sample fails to show significant results with regard to risk tolerance, contrary to the findings of Rosen et al. (1991) who show that SR investors are ‘somewhat risk averse’. This result is consistent with a lesser focus on the risk–return relation. SR investors are performance and fee conscious, but are not focusing on the trade-off with risk.

sec.title: 5. Conclusions
sec.p: In this study we survey Australian SR investors and seek to understand their preferences in SRI fund investing. Our online survey covers SEE characteristics, preferences in investment styles and characteristics including risk and return attitudes and preferences and demographics. In our core analysis, we estimate a series of ordered probit models where the dependent variable is a categorical variable based on ranges in the percentage of their budget used to invest in SR mutual funds.

To assess the SEE characteristics we ask participants to identify issues, relevant to them, from a list of 37 social, environmental and ethical concerns. Using a PCA we find four relevant categories: social conscience, including community-related issues; environmental, including mining and nuclear power; social/health issues, including abortion and alcohol; and social/environmental component, including gambling and greenhouse gases. However, in our probit analysis we find Australian investors are more focused on social and social/health issues as opposed to environmental issues.

The importance of fund characteristics is assessed across a number of questions. Our PCA shows that investors focus on fees, age and size of the fund, and performance. In the probit analysis, fees and performance are important to investors. In terms of the investors’ style, there is representation from both exclusionary and inclusionary investors and some do prefer to exclude specific companies, regions or industries. However, the only significant style coefficient is the exclusion of some regions. We conclude that Australian SR investors seek to satisfy both performance and social objectives, yet the group is heterogeneous with respect to their individual investment style.

We also develop a risk tolerance variable from questionnaire responses but find this variable is not significant in SR investment. Indeed, the descriptive analysis of the questionnaire responses shows that the sample comprises a wide cross-section of investors, from very risk averse to less risk averse.

The results from this study show that Australian SR fund investors are a heterogeneous group with varying risk preferences. They are both fee and performance conscious as well as socially responsible. Indeed, they focus on social conscience and social health issues as opposed to environmental concerns. Our study complements the vast literature using performance-based analysis where researchers question the relative performance of SRI with conventional investment alternatives. While the results from these studies are mixed, many show that SR investors are not necessarily financially penalized (see for example Asmundson and Foerster, 2001; Cummings, 2000; Statman, 2000). Our results show that SR investors are indeed fee and performance conscious. We conclude that SR investors, although they have a social conscience, are financially aware.

Other interesting results found by Woodward (2000) related demographic variables with individual criteria. In order to do that, she applied factorial analysis to reduce the number of criteria.
